items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:00 PM Concerning D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. Re: Violations of Public Contract Code Sections 4104 and 4106; Consideration of Hearing Officer’s Findings and Recommendations and Additional Evidence; Discussion and/or Action Regarding Imposition of Remedies as Allowed by Law (Public Contract Code Section 4110) and Contract
	 
	 
Per Board Resolution 2011-2012-15, Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle conducted a public hearing on December 2, 2011, to hear and consider evidence whether D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. violated the Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act (Public Contract Code Sections 4100 – 4114 (the “Act”)) in connection with the Yerba Buena High School Title IX modernization Project.  At the time of the hearing D.L. Falk asserted that it did not receive adequate notice of the hearing.
	 
Attached are the findings and recommendations of Marcus Battle.  As noted in Mr. Battle’s findings, the evidence supports that DL Falk was provided timely and adequate notice of the December 2, 2011, hearing.  Nevertheless, In light of DL Falk’s assertion that it not receive adequate notice, this matter has been agendized as a further public hearing by the Board so that the Board may consider Mr. Battle’s findings and recommendations as well as allow DL Falk an additional opportunity to present any additional information and evidence to the Board for its consideration.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:    
That the Board consider any additional information presented by DL Falk at the time of the hearing, and thereafter adopt the findings and recommendations as presented.

Members of the public may address the Board on any subject not on tonight’s agenda; however, provisions of the Brown Act (Government Code section 54954.2(a) and .3) preclude any action.  As an unagendized item, no response is required from the Board of District staff and no action can be taken; however, the Board may instruct the Superintendent to agendize the item for a future meeting.  When your name is called, please come to the podium, state your name for the record, and limit your remarks to three (3) minutes.
	 
Persons wishing to address the Board must fill out a gold request form, which is located at the entrance of the Board Room.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Superintendent Search:
Proposed Salary and Approval of Application
	 
	 
	 
Recent changes in the Brown Act call for any discussions / actions regarding salaries of superintendents to be conducted during open session of a regularly scheduled board meeting.  As such, attached is information from Ray and Associates, Inc. listing a sample of current salaries for superintendents in California and the United States.   The salary range determined by the Board of Trustees is included within the district profile as a part of the application packet.  Ultimately, the final salary and benefits package for the successful candidate will be negotiated and determined based upon proven experience, qualifications and meeting Board criteria.
	 
The attached “Application for Superintendent of Schools” is for the Board’s review and consideration for approval.  The revised application reflects district review with appropriate modifications to the section regarding “Background Check and Information.”   While space appears to be limited in some areas candidates are directed to attach extensive supplemental information.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees recommend a salary range of $ ________ to be used in the district profile information developed by Ray and Associates, Inc.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the application form as presented.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  11.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Dale Scott, Financial Advisor from Dale Scott & Company
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Adoption of Resolution 2011/2012-18 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2012 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $149,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District
			 
			 
The East Side Union High School District has determined to initiate proceedings for the refunding of all or a portion of three series of General Obligation Bonds which were authorized at an election held on March 5, 2002.  The three series of prior bonds to be refunded consist of the 2002 Series C Bonds which were issued in the aggregate principal amount of $50,000,000 on July 28, 2004; the 2002 Series D Bonds which were issued in the aggregate principal amount of $70,000,000 on June 2, 2005, and the 2002 Series E Bonds which were issued in the aggregate principal amount of $29,999,529.45 on June 16, 2005.  The 2002 Series B Bonds are subject to redemption on August 1, 2012, and the other two series of bonds are subject to redemption on August 1, 2013.
			 
Attached for your review is the Bond Resolution which authorizes the issuance and sale of 2012 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the maximum amount of $149,000,000, and approves all related financing documents and closing documents.  The Bond Resolution authorizes all or any portion of the three prior bond issues to be refunded based on market conditions which are prevailing at the time of the bond sale.  The Bond Resolution authorizes the Refunding Bonds to be sold on a negotiated basis.
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$149,000,000 (not to exceed)
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E Bonds
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution 2011/2012-18 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2012 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $149,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  11.05
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Lindsey Corbin, Director of Business Development for Chevron Energy Solutions
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Solar Incentive for Calero High School
			 
The District has expressed an interest in adding the new Calero High School to the District’s Solar PV Energy Savings Program.  The Solar program at ESUHSD has been a great success and by adding the new Calero High School, this will further the success of the program and bring additional savings to the district.  The District has a unique opportunity to reserve California Solar Incentive (CSI) Incentive funds for the Calero High School.  PG&E had closed down the program, however, the CPUC has refunded the program with $200 million to allow for the completion of the solar incentive program’s remaining steps (8, 9, &10). 
			 
If Solar is implemented at Calero High School, the project is projected to produce about $1.5 million in savings to the District over a 25 year period.  The district could also expect to receive over $91,000 in incentives dollars from PG&E over a five year period. The project initial infrastructure expense is expected to cost $675,000 and would not require any outlay from the District.  Chevron has arranged for low cost financing which will provide a benefit to the District in preserving its cash.  
			 
In order to move forward, the district must complete the application and cash reservation process to officially reserve the incentive (CSI) funding by making a deposit of $5,000 to PG&E by the February 17, 2012 deadline.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Consideration and Approval of Administrative Fee Agreement between 
District and D.L. Falk Construction, Inc.
	 
	 
Administration presents to the Board a draft proposed “Administrative Fee Agreement” between the District and D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. (“DLF”).  On June 28, 2011, the Board awarded the construction contract for the Yerba Buena High School Title IX Modernization Project (the “Project”) to D.L. Falk Construction, Inc.  in the total amount of $3,509,000.00.  DLF commenced work on the Project and the work is still underway and is expected to be completed within the next few months. 
	 
On November 17, 2011, the Board approved Resolution 2011/2012-15 appointing a hearing officer and directing the Hearing Officer to proceed with a public hearing under the Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act (Public Contract Code Sections 4100 – 4114 (the “Act”)) to determine whether DLF has violated the Act and, if so, whether or not the contract should be cancelled or, alternatively, the imposition of penalties is appropriate under the facts and circumstances as authorized by Public Contract Code section 4110.  A hearing was held by the Hearing Officer on December 2, 2011, and the Board held an additional public hearing on the matter at the January 19, 2012, Regular Board Meeting, but has not yet taken any final action on the matter.  DLF disputes that it has violated the Act.
	 
After further discussions with DLF, Administration recommends consideration and approval of the attached Administrative Fee Agreement to address this matter.  Pursuant to the agreement: (1) DLF will pay an administrative fee to the District in connection with the processing and handling of DLF’s August 2011 substitution request that gave rise to this matter; and (2) the Board will at this time refrain from taking any final action on the pending alleged violations; and (3) the Board will reserve the right to take final action on the pending alleged violations if and when the District receives allegations of further violations of the Act prior to final completion of the Project.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
DLF to pay administrative fee of $11,500 to the District.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Administrative fee funds to be deposited into Measure E fund.
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends the Board consider and approve the proposed Administrative Fee Agreement.

SUBJECT:
Receive Charter School Renewal Petition from Escuela Popular
	 
This item officially acknowledges that the Board of Trustees has received the Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center charter school renewal petition. The Board will hold a public hearing at the March 8, 2012 meeting to hear public comment on the renewal of the charter. The renewal petition will be evaluated by the district team and a recommendation will be presented to the Board at the April 19, 2012 meeting. The Board is required to render a renewal decision within sixty (60) days of receiving a renewal petition. The time frame for this renewal exceeds the sixty (60) day time requirement by four (4) days and this extension has been agreed to by administrators representing Escuela Popular. Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center charter school serves students grades K – 12.

SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
Student A
Student B
Student C
Student D

N/A

N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:

SUBJECT:
Approve Emergency One-Day School Closure for W.C. Overfelt High School on October 18, 2011
				 
The State form J-13A was submitted to the East Side Union High School District Board Members for approval at the November 2011 Board Meeting requesting attendance allowance to be waived for W.C. Overfelt High School due to a main water pipe breakage which left the school with no running water.  The school had taken attendance for 145 instructional minutes.  The attendance was below the statutory minimum day requirement of 180 minutes which resulted in the California Department of Education denying the attendance allowance waiver request that the District submitted.
				 
A revision was advised by California Department of Education to resubmit the J-13A to request a “one day” attendance waiver for a school emergency closure, since W.C. Overfelt H.S. did not achieve the minimum attendance allowance of 180 minutes requirement.
				 
The affidavit and supporting documents, if approved by County Superintendent, will be forwarded to the School Fiscal Services Division of the California Department of Education.   
				 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
				 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
				 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attendance waiver for the Emergency "One-Day" School Closure for W.C. Overfelt high School on October 18, 2011.

SUBJECT:
Consideration and Approval of Consent to Assignment and Assumption of Contracts
			 
Pursuant to contracts between the District and SGI, SGI is currently Program Manager for the Measure G and Measure E bond programs and is also construction manager for certain on-going District capital projects.  SGI has notified the District that it intends to transfer SGI’s assets to a new entity, SGI Construction Management, LLC.  A copy of SGI’s notice is included.  Pursuant to the program management and construction management agreements between the District and SGI, SGI is not permitted to transfer its interests under any of the contracts without the prior written consent of the Board.
			 
The District and SGI have prepared a form of Consent to Assignment and Assumption of Contracts for consideration by the Board.  The form of agreement clarifies that, if the Board approves the assignment and assumption, the assignee (SGI Construction Management, LLC) will be required to comply with all of the District’s current conflict of interest and billing/invoicing requirements under Board policy and District Administrative Regulations.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider the proposed assignment as requested by SGI.
